item.title: Things we’d like to have known before starting podcasting.
item.dc:creator: mark
item.content:encoded: We're still pretty new podcasters, and the learning curve is pretty steep. The early days of any podcast seem to be a blend of confusion and mistakes but also excitement and possibilities. There are though some things we wish we'd known before we got going. Echo has been a problem for us. We record at our homes and neither are an ideal studio environment so limiting room echo is something we wish we'd done earlier. Now we do everything possible to limit echo by covering glass surfaces (pulling the curtains basically) and softening and padding the area immediately below and surrounding the microphone, a large ‘bath towel’ works well. Keeping the microphone at mouth level or higher, sitting as close to it as is comfortable and turning down the gain also helps. For a two-person recording with one stereo microphone, we favoured sitting opposite each other to maximise channel separation. But that proved to be a bit of a problem for editing, so we now use the omni directional setting. We used to self host the podcast files, but this meant that tracking listener number involved a lot of guesswork as hits and downloads don't reliably reflect subscriber or listener numbers. We now host on Soundcloud, which means we can track listeners more accurately and provides some extra functionality too. Don’t put the podcast feed on a CDN. If the feed needs to be moved you’ll want to be able to use rewrites (.htaccess or similar) to tell client apps that it’s moved, and most CDNs don’t make provision for this.Never apply a ‘destructive’ process to the original recording. Stick a backup on Dropbox or something for a rainy day the second recording stops. We still have much to learn, but the one thing we always try to focus on is to make good content, and enjoy the ride.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: The problem with "scope creep" is the same for all small contractors in any industry. Working in construction, I generally find just simply saying "yes we can do that, you know it will cost extra, don't you?", although a little blunt, does away with any possible future misunderstandings. That having been said, if your quote is clearly written without ambiguous terminology and well itemized, it shouldn't be a problem anyway. You also talked about what we call "mates rates". The best piece of advice I received was that if you want to knock some money off the price, do it at the end. If the job has taken longer than thought, you can charge the full price, if it's gone well and you're feeling generous at the time of billing, you can decide then. However, if you've tied yourself in to a cheap price, chances are you'll keep putting the job off anyway and it will be a problem both for you and your friend.

item.title: Hello world I guess.
item.dc:creator: mark
item.content:encoded: Welcome to the Relative Paths site. This is the belated internet equivalent of  smashing a bottle of champagne on the bow of our podcast. We're still quite new to this podcasting lark, just 6 episodes in, but we've had a blast so far and we plan to be in it for the long haul. We'll be covering a variety of topics, from specific tekky stuff to more philosophical areas of the web design and development experience. We're aiming for one show every week and we try, but usually fail, to keep each episode to half an hour... we really do like to talk. We plan to have interviews soon, both with web industry folk and those on the client side too. We're also putting together a playlist of music we like to listen to whilst coding. You can play it from the sidebar if you have Spotify or follow the link to it above. We'd like to hear from you, how you got to hear about us, subjects you'd like us to cover in future episodes and anything you have to say about what we discuss in the podcast, so please leave us a comment or two on the site. If you want to get in touch with us directly, or follow us on Twitter, our contact details are down in the footer. We'll also be seeking some sponsors at some point soon, so if you'd like to work with us please do get in touch. Right then, I'm working through a WordPress Advance Custom Fields tutorial so I'm going to get back to that. Hope you enjoy the show, and I hope we'll hear from you soon.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
From the way you were talking about Pathfinder for Mac OS X, and about how useful the command line is, I think you should really consider trying Ubuntu or Elementary OS. They're just as developer-focused and user-friendly as Mac OS X, and Elementary OS looks just like Mac OS X, but they're not restricted in the ways Mac OS X is.
For example, Nautilus (the main Ubuntu file manager) has a hierarchical view, you can open the terminal from a right click, it does copy and paste, and it integrates with NFS, SMB (Samba), and of course Dropbox/Google Drive/Insert-cloud-service-here.

Very interesting Leo. I've used Linux for firewalls, gaming servers and of course web servers, but never (seriously) as a day-to-day OS. Do you use Ubuntu or Elementary OS for web development yourself? If so how do you get on with finding alternatives to popular web dev tools, or are most of them available for *nix? I'm thinking of Creative Cloud apps, IDEs and things like Sketch. I do like the idea of OS level cloud service integrations! [B]

I use Ubuntu for the most part, but Elementary OS is just Ubuntu with some UI changes.
Creative Cloud isn't available, but Inkscape (vector graphics), GIMP/Pinta (raster graphics), and other Free/Open Source tools make up for that, for zero cost (except your time, of course), at least for me.
As for IDEs, I use WebStorm and PyCharm from JetBrains, both of which have Linux as a first class platform, and anything that can't run natively will usually run in WINE, a very fast compatibility layer for Windows EXEs.
In the end, it all comes down to compatibility. If there's an application you just can't live without that's not compatible, and there's no FOSS alternative (which there almost always is), you can't switch.
Aside from that, it's better in pretty much every way than proprietary OSes, primarily because it's more configurable. Don't like the default Unity desktop? Use GNOME. Don't like the GNOME desktop? Use the K Desktop Environment, the Xfce desktop, the Light Extensible Desktop Environment, or one of the more exotic desktops like xmonad (a purely functional desktop in Haskell) or awesome (which is configured via C header files). The same goes for every piece of the OS. This could lead to extreme confusion, but Ubuntu and distributions like it provide some very useable and sane defaults, which makes it easier to use (in my opinion, and my mother's, who is anything but tech savvy) than Windows.
The other awesome thing is that most components of the OS are open source. If you don't like the way something works, chances are that someone has forked it and rewritten it in a way you'll like better, and if not, you can do so yourself (or file a bug against the project, if you're willing to wait).
So I suggest that you try it. It might not be for you, but the investment of time to try out Ubuntu is pretty minimal (a couple of hours to install the OS and your applications, and configure them), and the monetary investment is pretty much zero (unless you want to pay JetBrains lots of money for WebStorm Pro, which I've never needed but you might).

Brilliant, very comprehensive. Mind if I read this out when we do our Mac v's PC episode soon? I'd like to make more people aware of the 'other' OS :)
I have an old-ish PC hanging about, I think I'll put Elementary OS on it and have a play.
Thanks! [B]

Go ahead! I'm always happy to spread the word about Linux :)
I hope it works well for you!

Hello, it's me, the annoying Linux user!
I'm not going to go through the whole answer I did last time, because it's still on the other post. I just want to ask one thing: Forget the 1990s quote about "Linux is only free if your time is worthless" and look up "elementary OS".
It's a Linux distribution that keeps the flexibility of Linux (with a proper command line like Mac OS plus the ability to install huge amounts of free software) with a curated App Store-like software center like Mac OS.
It's got strict User Experience guidelines, like Mac OS, and inclusion in the Software Center requires stringent review. It's got excellent hardware support for modern computer.
It's my platform of choice for gaming, development work, and pretty much everything else.
http://elementary.io https://www.wired.com/2013/11/elementaryos/
A note about that quote: it was originally said in response to the launch of Fedora with practically no graphics hardware support. It's not at all relevant anymore. Yes, installing a new operating system and getting used to it takes time. In the case of, say, Windows, that costs money as well; in the case of good Linux distributions like Ubuntu, elementary, Mint, and others, that only costs time, and perhaps a five pound USB drive.

Duly noted. And as I haven't used Linux I didn't mean to sound dismissive. I'll mention your comment on an upcoming podcast. Actually, Linux could be a good subject for a Podcast. We'll have a think about that.
